news.header: Microsoft is starting a private beta for its iPhone keyboard
news.body: Microsoft has its own mobile operating system, but that hasn't stopped it from opening a public beta for a new iPhone keyboard.

news.header: Microsoft sues U.S. government over data gag orders
news.body: Microsoft wants a federal court to invalidate part of a 1986 law that it alleged has been abused by the government when authorities demand customers' data.

news.header: Why AI still needs us: To build quantum computers
news.body: We humans may still be licking our wounds following AI's victory at the ancient game of Go, but it turns out we still have something to be proud of.

news.header: Secretive Intel quietly woos makers in China
news.body: Intel's launched new robotics and drone developer kits at the low-key IDF trade show in Shenzhen.

news.header: Microsoft sues US government over secret requests for user data
news.body: Microsoft has sued the U.S. government in an attempt to strike down a law allowing judges to gag tech companies when law enforcement agencies want access to their users' data.

news.header: EU gives companies two years to comply with sweeping new privacy laws
news.body: Companies could face massive fines in 25 European Union countries if they mishandle citizens' personal information, under a new privacy law due to take effect in 2018.

news.header: Ransomware authors use the bitcoin blockchain to deliver encryption keys
news.body: Ransomware authors are using the bitcoin blockchain, which serves as the cryptocurrency's public transaction ledger, to deliver encryption keys to users.

news.header: Renogy's solar generator charges in 3 hours, offers 900 watt hours of power
news.body: Solar energy company Renogy today announced a mobile generator that uses a solar panel to charge in as little as three hours, and has an interchangeable battery, enabling longer use.

news.header: Lack of confidence proving to be real killer for women in technology
news.body: A pair of studies released this week shed light on challenges -- including career advancement and equal pay -- facing women in technology.

news.header: Internet of pants? This ultrathin thread could make your clothes part of the IoT
news.body: Your clothes could one day monitor your fitness levels or boost your smartphone reception thanks to a new technique that uses ultrathin electronic thread to embroider circuits into fabric.

news.header: Cyberattack could knock out huge swath of US electric grid, lawmakers say
news.body: The U.S. government is not prepared for a cyberattack on the electrical grid that takes out power over a large area for weeks, or even months, some lawmakers said.

news.header: Google Photos update brings emoji search, manual backup for local images and video
news.body: Emoji search is a neat exercise in image recognition, though it's unlikely to be useful for serious search queries.

news.header: Sharp's robot smartphone coming in May for $1,800
news.body: Japan's Sharp will launch in May a smartphone that's built into a humanoid robot. Or is it a humanoid robot with a built-in smartphone?

news.header: Chrome abandons XP, Vista and older versions of OS X
news.body: Google released Chrome 50, and as promised last year, dropped support for Windows XP and Vista, along with three older editions of Apple's OS X.

news.header: EU plan to collect, not share, air traveler data is â€˜absurd'
news.body: Air passengers entering or leaving the European Union will have their movements kept on file by police authorities from 2018 under draft legislation approved by the European Parliament.

news.header: Optional Windows update aims to protect Microsoft wireless mice against hijacking
news.body: Microsoft issued an optional update to protect Windows computers against an attack that could hijack wireless mice to execute malicious commands.
